div1.p: Kean comments on the Cornwell painting of the Reed Board and the distribution of proper credit between Reed and Finlay.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Harold W. Jones, February 20, 1942 [Enclosed in 06310040]
div1.opener:
2804 N St., N. W.
Feb. 20, 1942
Copy
My dear Colonel Jones
div1.p:
Anything relating to the episode of Walter
Reed and yellow fever is of interest to me and I
have great regard also for the work that Dr. Philip
S. Hench has been doing in the time he could spare
from a busy professional life to make an exhaustive
study of the whole episode and the part contributed
by each of Reed's assistants to the work of the Y.F.
Board. I don't know just what the two Cuban
versions of the painting are to which you refer but
in the painting of Mr. Cornwell which they sent me
Reed certainly occupies the center of the stage
and is not at all in the background - nor do I
see any resemblance to a stuffed shirt in his
attitude or expression. It is Dr. Carlos Finlay
who is off on one side. I think that his
contribution was a very important one and altho.
his experiments on men were failures, as were
the first series by the Reed Board, he had
sound epidemiological arguments for his theory
which I know impressed Reed because he
repeated them to me. I always give Finlay
the credit for the discovery and the identification
of the genus of mosquito which was the vector,
and also for inventing the technique by which
2
the stegomyia can be carried to the patient for infection,
and to the volunteer for experiment in a test tube with
a cotton stopper. But you cannot make a common
pungens bite that way. She just won't do it. But
while Finlay's work convinced nobody in 19 years,
Reed's demonstration convinced the medical world.
As Dr. Goldberger of the P.H.S. expressed it. Walter
Reed's demonstration “converted a discredited hy-
pothesis into an established doctrine”.

John H. Musser in his Internal Medicine Lea &
Febiger 1932 does not mention Finlay's name in
the page devoted to the History of Yellow-Fever.
The Cubans in their monument to Finlay do not
mention the name of Reed, tho. they do have Lazear's
name on it. Both were wrong. I do not think
that well educated Americans should take part in
the squabble as to the credit of each. I was
present at the dinner given by the doctors of Havana
to Finlay to celebrate the demonstration by Reed
and his assistants of the Finlay theory. Finlay,
Reed, General Wood and I think Gorgas were
there tho. Gorgas had not accepted “the rôle of
the mosquito as the only or even the usual way
of conveying the disease”, nor had he two months
later when Gen. Wood put him to work on the
mosquito campaign. Dr. John Guiteras touched
3
on the question of relative credit in a beautiful
speech in which he compared Finlay to
Patrick Manson and Reed to Ronald Ross in
their work on the rôle of the mosquito in
malaria. This seemed to us all to be a fair
division of the credit at that time. (Dec. 22, 1900)
and I have seen no reason to alter my
opinion since.
Thanks for your letter.
